standby node or would call multi AZ multiple availability zones the multi AZ solution is another database instance
with its own storage so you it's a high availability solution but it's also a bit of a disaster recovery solution
within the same region but across multi AZ you have duplication of all of the
aspects of the database Aurora though has very high availability but achieves
it differently it uses all three availability zones for even higher availability and durability at the
storage layer so the separate read replica doesn't have its own data storage it's part of a shared storage
that striped across three AZ's two different architectures but the Aurora architecture is designed for even faster
failover as you can see because of the way the synchronous and asynchronous writes happen on the RDS side which is
still very very highly performant we have a lot of customers running on RDS but we're able to increase that
performance and shorten that availability fail over time with the Amazon RDS architecture so six-way
replication of storage what that means is every piece of data in its own chunk
resides six different places across three availability zones and in order to
do a write you only need a quorum of four in order to do the right means you can return results faster but also from
an availability standpoint you can lose two of those places where the data is and still have four copies of that data
to be very very resilient and very very durable if you're doing a read you only need three copies of those data so you
can lose and you can see you could lose an entire availability zone but still have three copies of the data in order
to continue to do your your write your reads as well so the ability to survive
catastrophic failures within one region we'll talk later about multiple region technologies as well so but it's it's
this is logical the volume is really striped across hundreds and hundreds of storage notes and you do not have to
provision ahead of time all the provisioning is done in a dynamic fashion scaleable read replicas both RTS
and Aurora support the concept of read replicas the value of a read replicas is that you're offloading the compute and
from the querying times so there may be some workloads that are read-only workloads that you can offload and to a
read replicas and not take the performance away from your production or from your transactional node so it
leaves the pressure on the databases within one region but we also now support cross region read replicas so
you have a read replicas in another region that you can bring your data closer to your constituents and also as
a high availability disaster recovery strategy as well you can upgrade the Reeb replicas to a new version and as I
said it's supported for both Aurora and the RDS flavors but the read replicas as
I showed you on the RDS side have their own storage whereas on the Aurora side
since there's a shared storage that read replicas is near real-time with your
production database because it's sharing your storage we've had a number of customers tell us that they didn't even
realize that they had failed over to a read replicas just because it was almost instantaneous because the storage was
consistent across you could have up to 15 read replicas on both RDS and Aurora
and also you can set up your failover you can say first try to failover to know to read replicas 1 then 2 then 3
then 4 so there's a very granular control that have across your read replicas and very
very low latency low lag we're seeing less than 10 milliseconds lag in your
your environments there so let's talk

of processing that needs to take takes a little bit extra time what we've done part of the things that made Aurora

querying technology that instant crash recovery can happen in a parallel

happen there's another technology that I'm very excited about
it's called database backtrack let's say somebody does something to a database that you don't want to have happen

the database that you want to be able to go back to this introduces the concept of a safe point the other safe point and
you can backtrack or you can roll back the database to that point in time but it's not the same as a full database
recovery where you've taken the entire database back to that point in time that's a destructive operation this is
not a destructive operation you can bring it back several times to that backtrack area and view the database as
it existed at a previous point in time and you know so it protects against the
unintentional DML in DDL it's non-destructive and also very useful in QA we'll have a lot of times where
